page.description: An important part of writing any program is handling potential errors properly. You should do the same when writing an Xbasic script, making sure it can recover from some common run-time errors (e.g., when a file is not found, the disk is full, or the table is opened exclusively by another session or user).

section.description: To react appropriately to specific run-time errors, you can use the ERROR_CODE_GET() and ERROR_TEXT_GET() functions to obtain the error code and error message returned by the most recent run-time error. Use these functions in an error handling routine (established by an ON ERROR GOTO statement) to compare the error code against one or more of the possible error codes that might occur.
section.note: User error messages should have a number in the range 16000 to 16999.

section.title: How to Structure an Error Handler
section.description: For example, the general format of your error handler might be as follows:
section.example: error_handler: err = error_code_GET() select case err = resume next case err = resume next ... case else msg = error_text_GET(err) ui_msg_box("Error", msg, UI_ATTENTION_SYMBOL) end end select end

description.p: Each CASE of the SELECT statement is for a different error. If an error occurs for which you have not included a CASE, a default message box will display the error message and then end the script.
The following table displays run-time error codes and their corresponding error messages:

item.description: Comma expected for function's next argument
Function returns incorrect type of data
Expression too complex - maximum RP length exceeded
Operator can't be used with this data
Operation returns string which exceeds maximum length
Invalid number of arguments in CASE
Record number is past end of table
Not supported for this index type
One or more records not found
That range is not currently active
That relation is not currently active
Table already has a parent relation
Table has too many child relations
Table out of memory for entries
For integrity, use parent field name
For integrity, use child field name
Entry is not a display entry
Data value cannot fit into a numeric field of size
Table in use by another user or window
No tags specified for compound index
It is possible that your indexes have become corrupted. Try to update indexes by right-clicking on the table in the Control Panel and choose the Update Indexes command.
Unable to drop key from tag
RI error: parent table is entering
